I highly recommend it - just for an hour or two of retail therapy when you\u2019ve been gone from shopping too long!!!!

address.streetAddress: Av. Insurgentes Km. 5.025 s/n local A1 Plaza Las Americas

651899131.name: (Almost) Everything you need
651899131.author: a TripAdvisor user
651899131.reviewBody: A good place to spend few hours, to do shopping or eat something. Easy to reach with public transport.

address.streetAddress: Av. Insurgentes Km. 5.025 s/n local A1 Plaza Las Americas

554571612.name: Girls day out!
554571612.author: a TripAdvisor user
554571612.reviewBody: We had taken the boat from Corozal to Chetumal for the day! Liverpool was wonderful! Great deals! My only suggestion when traveling into Mexico is either you can speak Spanish or have some one with you who does!! Worth the trip!

address.streetAddress: Av. Insurgentes Km. 5.025 s/n local A1 Plaza Las Americas

667665331.name: Fun activity
667665331.author: a TripAdvisor user
667665331.reviewBody: We walked to the zoo on a hot sunny mid-day and it was worth the walk.  True, it isn\'t like some big fancy zoos, but we enjoyed it.  It was a good activity to do while in Chetumal.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Insurgentes Javier Rojo Gomezfrente Fovissste

649670001.name: Great little view but please rehome that tiger!
649670001.author: a TripAdvisor user
649670001.reviewBody: On my visit with my little girl we really enjoyed seeing the animals there aren\u2019t many but the ones there are have pretty nice enclosures. The panthers had lovely space and different enrichment. I do think this zoo is a very nice half day out and my daughter really liked it. \n\nHowever the tiger upset me it is so large and the cage is so so small I can only hope the zoo is building a new enclosure like the other big cats. I can see there is no enrichment and it is suffering psychologically. Please please take note of the tiger reviews.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Insurgentes Javier Rojo Gomezfrente Fovissste

640611701.name: Poor Tiger
640611701.author: a TripAdvisor user
640611701.reviewBody: Not the greatest zoo in the world, but when we came across that poor, really big tiger lying in his really small cage with the smell of his urine so pungent it made our eyes water, it was one of the saddest things we\'ve ever seen. This tiger must be freed from this sad sad sad habitat! Peta, where are you?

address.streetAddress: Avenida Insurgentes Javier Rojo Gomezfrente Fovissste

640610123.name: Tiger
640610123.author: a TripAdvisor user
640610123.reviewBody: Most of the animals in the zoo are fake - the giraffe, the hippo - so when we saw the huge tiger from a distance, laying dead-still on a table in his very small cage, we thought he was fake, also. But he wasn\'t. As we got close, we could see he was breathing. As we got closer we we were overwhelmed by the stench of his urine. I am not an avid animal rights person by any means, but this magnificent beast should NOT be in this horrid zoo, wallowing in its foulness. FREE THE CHETUMAL TIGER!

address.streetAddress: Avenida Insurgentes Javier Rojo Gomezfrente Fovissste

594167235.name: amazing
594167235.author: a TripAdvisor user
594167235.reviewBody: it is the most beatiful, it is the most amazing place. The service was excellent and it is very entertaining. \nI liked it a lot and I recommend it the service is good and comfortable.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Insurgentes Javier Rojo Gomezfrente Fovissste

542329379.name: Something different do in Chetumal
542329379.author: a TripAdvisor user
542329379.reviewBody: Good entertainment for 20 pesos, you can see it used to be a lovely property but sadly has now fallen into disrepair.  Some of the exhibits were closed, like the hippopotamus which I had really wanted to see. I also was not able to find the Tigers.  If you are going with small children be sure to keep a close eye on them because there were several spots which seemed like an accident waiting to happen.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Insurgentes Javier Rojo Gomezfrente Fovissste

504738031.name: Trip with Family
504738031.author: a TripAdvisor user
504738031.reviewBody: It is a large zoo. I liked it. The train was a lot of fun, it goes around the zoo and you can see the animals from a different point of view.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Insurgentes Javier Rojo Gomezfrente Fovissste

485025440.name: family trip
485025440.author: a TripAdvisor user
485025440.reviewBody: excellent choice for families, we enjoy it every time, don\'t forget to visit the tiger... huge! good snacks.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Insurgentes Javier Rojo Gomezfrente Fovissste

454846043.name: Lots of potential
454846043.author: a TripAdvisor user
454846043.reviewBody: We visited this zoo in January, 2017. The cost is very minimal. Upon entering you quickly envision that it was once was thriving and had better days. There are some animals. Some exhibits are now closed. Perhaps if they had a new manager with vision, and funding.

address.streetAddress: Avenida Insurgentes Javier Rojo Gomezfrente Fovissste

444352385.name: Enjoyed it very much
444352385.author: a TripAdvisor user
444352385.reviewBody: Took my son for the first time when he was 11 months and absolutely loved it. He was thrilled with all the animals and plants. Can\'t wait to take him this coming week now at (2years).

address.streetAddress: Avenida Insurgentes Javier Rojo Gomezfrente Fovissste

504738533.name: Excellent room of virtual reality!
504738533.author: a TripAdvisor user
504738533.reviewBody: It was very nice to visit the room of virtual reality. It took us to many places in Quintana Roo but the best was the view from the pole of Los Voladores de Papantla!!!!!

address.streetAddress: Av insurgentes

666192193.name: Amazing ruins
666192193.author: a TripAdvisor user
666192193.reviewBody: The temp hit 46 degrees as we arrived. And the shade only helped a tiny bit. The ruins are nothing short of amazing, monkeys sleeping in the trees, the heat probably getting to them too. At the main site We were one of 7, and that included 2 staff. At the second site we had the temples to ourselves (and the Mayan spirits). You can climb the steep temple steps of multiple buildings, the views pretty damn special from the top. One of the temple\u2019s steps were so steep my legs almost quivered. It was a privilege to interact with such an amazing archeological site especially since we had it to ourselves.

652992534.name: A hidden world of beauty, ruins, trees, birds, monkeys and more
652992534.author: a TripAdvisor user
652992534.reviewBody: $60 pesos per person. Sundays free for residents. Perfect spot to view Mayan ruins. Extra fee for profesional photography equipment, worth the drive.

650180325.name: Delightful Mayan Ruin Site
650180325.author: a TripAdvisor user
650180325.reviewBody: I preferred it to the larger Kohunlich. It was more overgrown with jungle and gave you a tomb raiders feel. There were seceral large structures to climb on.

647249326.name: Clear understanding of centuries old culture
647249326.author: a TripAdvisor user
647249326.reviewBody: The area is beautiful; the history of the ruins very impressive; guides very knowledgeable and interested in sharing their culture.

646620585.name: Not much to see but still worth it.
646620585.author: a TripAdvisor user
646620585.reviewBody: I\'ve been here twice and after you\'ve seen it twice you\'ve seen it all but it\'s still worth going. It\'s a walk but if my mother could do it with two fake knees I think anyone can. \n

645203527.name: two sites in one
645203527.author: a TripAdvisor user
645203527.reviewBody: we liked Kohunlich more then Dzibanche, visiting both sites by taxi from Chetumal. Leaving at 8 AM, we were back in town by 3 PM. the taxi charged us 1000 Peso, and he deserved a tipp. We came to Dzibanche at noon, just to see three big tourbuses leaving. besides the main Dzibanche site, there is a small site nearby, included in the same entrance ticket: Kinichna. This is only one bigger temple, nice to see, but if you are short in time you can drop it without loss.

644313452.name: As allways amazing
644313452.author: a TripAdvisor user
644313452.reviewBody: As a fan of Maya archeology this is a Maya site worth visiting including the neighboring Kinichna. One can visit this site with a short drive from Chetumal where it would be recommended tostay.

643329956.name: Worth the drive
643329956.author: a TripAdvisor user
643329956.reviewBody: We (my adult son and I) booked our tour to Dzibanche with Native Tours about a month before our cruise ship stop in Casa Maya.  When we arrived at the office, we were asked if we would like to visit a different site but declined.  That meant that we were lead to a car by David who the took us on a private tour of the site!  It was Awesome!  David is an amazing guide, full of history and knowledge of archeological sites around the world.  We appreciate that we were not pressured into a different tour and cannot say enough about David.  Recognize that it is two hours each way to Dzibanche but when you arrive you will be glad you made the effort.  We saw fewer than twenty other people when we were there.  The grounds are well kept and there are restrooms at the entrance.  David provided us with cold drinks and lunch.  It is a not-to-be-missed experience.

642466527.name: Beautiful and very few tourists
642466527.author: a TripAdvisor user
642466527.reviewBody: This is a further drive from cruise ports, but if you travel with Native Choice, they share many interesting stories along the way that make very good use of the travel time.\n\nUpon entering the ruins, the present day slips away and you are transported to a place lost to the rest of the world where monkeys swing in the trees overhead and colorful birds call out their songs all around you. It is easy to reimagine the history and the ceremonies that took place here without the bustle of other tourists, because, besides the two other couples in our group, we only saw five other people while there, one of whom was caretaker for the grounds.

642465211.name: Clearly underrated!!
642465211.author: a TripAdvisor user
642465211.reviewBody: Not so far away from Chetumal, very few tourists (contrary to Tulum, Coba or Chichen) although it compares quite well to these other cities. Kinichna is in the same site and is very nice too. Clearly worth the detour !!

641354978.name: Incredible
641354978.author: a TripAdvisor user
641354978.reviewBody: We love to travel and it\u2019s difficult to see something preserved as well  like this ruins.\nBring comfortable shoes...

639762913.name: Excursion
639762913.author: a TripAdvisor user
639762913.reviewBody: Visited as a part of cruise ship excursion. Absolutely worth visit and highly recommend visiting until place becomes more know and some restrictions might be put to place.

637856053.name: Another Mayan gem
637856053.author: a TripAdvisor user
637856053.reviewBody: Having been to quite few Mayan ruins, you always think you are prepared for what is the next one and yet it is always something different and unique, thoroughly enjoyed this visit, well worth the long drive

613496185.name: Our Favorite
613496185.author: a TripAdvisor user
613496185.reviewBody:
We actually wound up here by fate...security issues forced the cancellation of our plans in Cozumel.  So we booked Dzibanche at the last minute...we are so glad we did.

The bus ride was lengthy, but by the time you got there you felt like you had actually seen a bit of real Mexico and not just the highly commercialized and relatively culturally sanitized cruise ports.  

The site is truly at the backside of nowhere, but good thing is this means ( or at least for us meant) smaller crowds.  There was only one other bus load of cruisers while we were there.  

The ruins are impressive...multiple tall pyramids and a variety of other structures.  A nice bonus here is next to nothing is roped off...you have free run to climb and explore at YOUR OWN RISK.  Seriously, it’s a place you need to careful as the pyramids are deceptively steep.  Some in our group who casually climbed were a little freaked out when they had to come down.  It’s definitely not an area where you want to have need of an ambulance or emergency medical care.

We loved it.

601919959.name: Dzibanche was ZEE Best!
601919959.author: a TripAdvisor user
601919959.reviewBody:
Do not let the long bus ride scare you away from this side trip from a cruise line.  We signed up off of the Norwegian Getaway.  YES, it was a 2 1/2 hour bus ride one way.  Our guide gave us information during the ride to the ruins.  It was informative and interesting.  The bus was modern and had a restroom at the rear.  It was well air conditioned.  Prior to entering the ruins, we stopped to get our entry tickets and restroom facilities were provided and it gave us a chance to stretch our legs.
We were told that this is one of the only set of ruins that allows you to climb the temples in Mexico any more.  It was interesting seeing workers restoring the ruins while we visited.  The North South temple is extremely impressive.  Some of the Temples still have the original red coloring on the stones to help you get an idea of what they looked like in their glory days.  
If you go in July, it is HOT but there are a lot of trees surrounding the area to take refuge from the heat.  The tour company provided us all with 2 bottles of water and a "bagged lunch".  Lunch consisted of a granola bar, banana and a candy bar in the AM along with a small bottle of water.  After visiting the Dzibanche ruins they gave us a Ham & Cheese sandwich on white bread with mayonnaise. (if you held the ham up it would be transparent LOL) and a larger bottle of water., however it did the job of sustaining us.  We then traveled @ 1/2 hour (closer to the port) to the Kohunlich ruins.  The Kohunlich ruins have the giant kohulich palm trees and these ruins have the beautiful Temple of the Masks. 
Make sure you bring a brimmed hat and sunscreen.  We also brought the Mosquito repellent bracelets to keep pests away.  There are no ropes to hold onto while climbing the ruins.  If you have balance issues, DO NOT CLIMB!  Also take precautions by leaning toward to steps while climbing and descending and be safe coming down by scooting down on your butt if necessary!

590511698.name: Early Pre-Classic Maya Site
590511698.author: a TripAdvisor user
590511698.reviewBody: Dzibanche is a major Maya archaeological site.  Archeologists believe Dzibamche may have been the seat of the Kan/Snake dynasty that ruled before Calakmul. Whereas Chizen Itza and Tulum in the upper Yucatan are relatively "new" sites from the Post-Classic period, Dzibanche appears to have been the Kan capital in the 5th and 6th centuries. If you are a Maya history buff, you will love this tour.

572967872.name: Very interesting ruins
572967872.author: a TripAdvisor user
572967872.reviewBody:
We went on a tour that including Dzibanche and Kohunlich.  The two sites are about 35 minutes apart.  Seeing the two together made for a very interesting day as they each have their interesting aspects.  We did this as a day excursion while on a cruise that stopped at Costa Maya.  You spend a couple of hours on the bus each way and get about an hour at each location.

According to our guide (and my memory!), the ruins at Dzibanche include more ritual areas.  They were pyramids used as part of religious activities.  It includes several pyramids that you can climb to look around and a few include interesting carvings.  I had previously been to San Gervaiso which includes much smaller ruins.  Being able to climb these tall pyramids provided an interesting view and perspective on the impressive architecture of the Mayans.

The ruins at Kohunlich cover a wider area and include more aspects of Mayan life.  They include residences, offices, religious activities, etc.  There is also a pyramid there that is named the Temple of the Masks and you get a great view of masks that were carved into the rock.  Walking around Kohunlich gives you more of a feel for what it must have been like for a Mayan person to walk around a town that they had built.

Together our group of tweens to adults found the sites very impressive and we thoroughly enjoyed the day.  We felt it was well worth the bus ride.

572702603.name: Beautiful ruins in the middle of nowehere
572702603.author: a TripAdvisor user
572702603.reviewBody:
The ruins of Dzibanche are totally amazing and astonishing!
If you are on the Yucatán peninsula you have to visit them, they are really breathtaking and something you do not see anywhere else on the Earth!
In the Dzibanche-area there are several ruins, some higher and some smaller. 
If my memory does not fail me it was three big ruins and several smaller.
The high ones are really spectacular and outstanding, you lost your breath when you saw them the first time, but the small ones are also interesting and fun to watch. 

You are allowed to climb and walk at all ruins, except one. There are two ruins that are high and gives a lovley view over the surrounding jungle, however you are allowed to climb at the smaller ruins, as well. I would recommend you to do that if you are there. However the steps are high and nothing for small children, elderly people, people with bad balance or people with fear of highs and people with leg- or kneeproblems. 
If you fall and break a foot you have to travel a long distance to the nearest hospital, so please walk slowly and carefully on the ruins.

There are also carvings from the mayan indians on one ruin, however the masks and carvings at the nearby ruins of Kohunlich are more spectacular (even though the ruins of Dzibanche are more spectacular), but they are still fun to watch and to think that there acctually lived people at Dzibanche a thousand years ago.

Some ruins at Dzibanche are not fully archeologically searched and dug out, so you can see some ruins covered with soil and trees, so you can almost feel like an explorer, exploring the temples and jungles of Central America.

Around the ruins of Dzibanche there is jungle and forests, so you can get shade when you look at the ruins, necessary, since there is always hot and sunny at the ruins of Dzibanche (do not forget to bring water and sunscreen with you). 
The paths and trails leading around at the ruins of Dzibanche are small, but not steep, and a bit uneven, since roots from trees are sometimes going over the paths and trails.
To visit the ruins of Dzibanche is possible for everyone, however persons with strollers, and wheelchairs may have big problems with the roots (see above).
Small children, teenagers and adults interested in history and culture will have a great time at the ruins of Dzibanche. It is hard not to like the ruins of Dzibanche.

The nearby (about 20 kilometers/30 minutes) ruins of Kohunlich are smaller, but whith much more carvings than the ruins at Dziabche. At Dzibanche you really lose your breath when you see the ruins the first time, you do not lose your breath at the ruins of Kohunlich.
However the masks and carvings are much more extensive at the ruins of Kohunlich, at Dzibanche there are only some smaller carvings and no masks. 
At Dzibanche there are only ruins that are temples and tombs, but at Kohunlich you get to see more different constructions: one temple, palaces, ruins of houses and a ball court. So the ruins of Kohunlich is more extensive and there are more numbers of them, at Dzibanche there are fewer ruins, but those who are, are higher. 
At Kohunlich you get a better understanding of how the mayans lived.
The ruins themselfs are more dramatic and more well preserved at Dzibanche, but the carvings are much more incredible at the ruins of Kohunlich. However the ruins of Dzibanche is not completely archeologially explored, which the ruins at Kohunlich is.
If you only have time to visit one of the ruins I would recommend you to visit Kohunlich.
If you are going to visit Chichén Itzá and only have time to see one of the ruins, I would recommend you to see Dzibanche, but if you will not see Chichén Itzá I would recommend you to visit Kohunlich.

If compare the ruins of Dzibanche to Chichén Itzá, the ruins of Dzibanche is much smaller, Chichén Itzá is both higher, wider, bigger and more breathtaking, but the ruins of Dzibanche are still outstanding and the fact that they are located in the middle of the jungle, in the middle of nowhere, far from big roads and civilasaition makes the ruins of Dzibanche even more spectacular, even though Chichén Itzá is more breathtaking. 
Dzibanche is also not turistic, there are no shops or vendors there, which makes the atmosphere more stressfree realxing and natural. At Chichén Itzá there are vendors and stores everywhere.
At Dzibanche there is almost no people at all (when I where there my group where the only one that was there), however at Chichén Itzá there is always a lot of people (even though it is not crowded).  

The ruins of Dzibanche are located in the middle of nowhere, in the middle of the Mexican jungle, far from big roads and towns, it is really remote, on the countryside.
It takes about two and a half hour from Costa Maya to the ruins of Dzibanche and on your way you pass sugarcane fields, banana-plantages, small villages where the locals sells pineappels, so as you can see, it is a charming trip, even though most of the trip is on very straight roads only with view of the jungle and very thick jungles (but then you can take a relaxing moment to sleep, so you are well rested when you arrive to the ruins). The roads are good and not bumpy and people drive rather carefully, so you can have a safe trip. Our bus had seat-belts.

I where at the ruins of Dzibanche (and Kohunlich) on a shore excursion, booked thorugh Norwegian Cruise Line and we had an amazing day, both at the ruins of Dzibanche, and at Kohunlich. We had an air-conditioned bus, which was very comfortable and a sandwhich (not vegeterian) and water bottles were provided. 
Our guide, Arturo was really good and told us everything we sought to know about the ruins.

If you are to visit the ruins of Dzibanche (which I hope you will) you really must bring water bottles with water, sunscreen, sunhat and something to eat with you, since there are absolutly no shops at the ruins of Dzibanche or nearby and there is often very hot and sunny. When I where there in April there were no mosquitos or nasty insects, but if you are to visit the ruins of Dzibanche I would still recommend you to bring insect repellent, since you never know if there is going to be mosquitos.
There are toilets, that you can use for free. 

I would really recommend you all to visit the lovley ruins of Dzibanche! 
You will not regret it!

569110949.name: Incredible! Well worth the short walk to their location.
569110949.author: a TripAdvisor user
569110949.reviewBody:
Our transport was spotlessly clean,  I thought it brand new, but I was told it was 2 years old.  We left dust footprints on the floor when we embarked.  THAT is clean!
Enrique could not have been a better guide.  He covered so many things on the 2 hr ride it amazed us.  I worry about his neck from turning backwards the entire time.  They should put a swivel seat in for him.
Our driver, Abel, made the trip easy as well.  Never worried about his skills.
Our bus held 10 but beside our group of 6, only 2 others joined us.  Fantastic.
We saw everything without any other interference (great for photos).
Next time, we'll take a longer tour with these two to lead us.
The lunch was excellent and very wlecome. (loved the Costo bottled water) and fresh.
Everything was handled impeccably and Enrique is VERY proud to work for Native Tours.  He praised them several times for their concern for safety, customer service and dedication to having happy employees.
It shows.
Don't go with anyone else.  THese folks are the real deal.  WELL WORTH THE SHORT WALK.

567736995.name: Beautiful
567736995.author: a TripAdvisor user
567736995.reviewBody: I went here with some friends with our Tour guide Pablo. The place is filled with culture and natural beauty. As soon as I walked, I felt the peace of the area. I wish to go again soon. There are Mayan ruins in which you can take pictures and climb on.

559124866.name: Very cool to compare/contrast with Kohunlich
559124866.author: a TripAdvisor user
559124866.reviewBody: We toured this ruin along with Kohunlich as a shore excursion from our cruise ship. The ship contracted with Native Choice for this tour, and seeing the two ruins the same day gave a unique opportunity to compare the two. Dzibanche is undoubtedly the larger of the two, although a significant portion has not yet been excavated. What has been exposed does not seem to follow the patterns of what is known of Mayan culture from other sites, making Dzibanche even more of a curiosity. Very cool tour.

556959977.name: Dzibanche with Native Choice
556959977.author: a TripAdvisor user
556959977.reviewBody: Having just returned from a western Caribbean cruise, there are many choices for shore excursions.  We usually try to book indepently.  This tour with Lorenzo was by far our favorite.  It gives an opportunity to go inland and visit the real area, rather than just the port.  Be sure to get and follow the map to Native Choice office.  After a short gathering period, the tour begins.  It is about 2 hours to Dzibanche, but the ride goes quickly as he gives an overview of all things involved: history of the Mayas, the area, current events.  Once you have arrived, he explains everything and allows time for pictures.  There is a short break before and after the ruins.  Then back to the port.  My husband and I asked as many questions as we could possible think of and he answered all of them!  It was easy to see he enjoyed his job.  We also totally enjoyed it. Thank you Lorenzo and Native Choice.

555739010.name: Glad I went!
555739010.author: a TripAdvisor user
555739010.reviewBody: This is a Mayan multi-pyramid site which was well worth the visit but you can read about the history, details, etc. elsewhere.  My experience was strongly influenced by my driver, a knowledgeable, personable and very interesting human being, Senor Jorge Ortiz, 983 11 60580.  He drove me to the pyramids, on the way we stopped for a Mexican breakfast, and talked the whole time about everything under the sun.  On my way back to Chetumal I told him I would go to the bus station since I was heading north to Tulum and he went out of his way 34 km (no extra charge) to drive me north to the town of Balaclava to look at a fort there and make my trip north shorter.  The price for all this was extremely reasonable.

555723613.name: Monkeys, lots of monkeys
555723613.author: a TripAdvisor user
555723613.reviewBody: This is a very large and very private ruin.  There are not a lot of buses coming in and out, and several times over a long period of time (I live about an hour from these ruins) I have found myself almost alone in looking at these gorgeous ruins.  It is surrounded by jungle and the howler moneys like to play in the ruins.  If you don\'t bother them they play and entertain you.

546624860.name: great site, with plenty to learn...bring the insect repelent
546624860.author: a TripAdvisor user
546624860.reviewBody: How can you rate a site that has been around for more than a millennium. Enjoy and learn. If this is to be your first time; read up of take an organized tour.

517942307.name: Time travel
517942307.author: a TripAdvisor user
517942307.reviewBody: To wander among these ancient stones with only spider and howler monkeys as company is magical.  I admit we had a guide -- very informative, gentle, lovely.  It is not as extensive (yet) as many of the ruins further north in Yucatan, but the jungle setting and wildlife is plus and the pyramides are impressive.  The rumor on the street was that a new set of ruins had been discovered and was in the hands of archaeologists -- the most extensive Mayan site to date.   Meanwhile, Dzibanche is well worth the effort.  We were in Chetumal with a rental car, so it was simple, but there were many public tours on offer.

492858983.name: Breathtaking
492858983.author: a TripAdvisor user
492858983.reviewBody: As part of a shore excursion we visited the pyramids of Dzibanche. Once you walk to the area the view is just breathtaking. It is so well kept and the surroundings are impressive! There are different pyramids in this area and you can tell that it was bug compound. From the Mask Pyramid to the area that used to be designed for competitions and sacrifices. Just knowing that your are walking on a place that the Mayans used to live and it was their kingdom it\'s a feeling that you just can\'t describe!

486193924.name: Mayan Ruin Tour
486193924.author: a TripAdvisor user
486193924.reviewBody: This was our first trip to see Mayan Ruins and took the longer tour to Dzibanche.  Both our tour guide (Casey) and driver (Melvyn) were first rate!  If this is your thing, it is worth the trip - good people!  I went with my two younger twenty children

480644071.name: Excellent off the beaten track site
480644071.author: a TripAdvisor user
480644071.reviewBody: We have visited most of Mexico\' big name Mayan sites (Chichen Itza, Palenque, Uxmal, Labna, Yaxchilan, Bonampak, etc) so it was great to be able to visit this more out of the way place. We were on a cruise docking at Costa Maya and took an excursion with Native Choice (reviewed separately - but they were excellent). The site is not manicured  like Chacchoben or Chichen Itza. It is quiet, with a different atmosphere to the more well-known sites - there were just a few people there. It is in a beautiful natural setting and it is perfectly clear that there is more to be discovered there (there are still archaeologists working on the site),\n\nAlthough it isn\'t as well set up as the large sites, there are toilet facilities on site and the pathways are accessible to most although you need to wear sensible footwear. You can still climb the temples, although for how much longer this will be permitted is unclear. Be warned they are very steep and there are no handrails!

480368008.name: Mayan Pyramid
480368008.author: a TripAdvisor user
480368008.reviewBody: Close to Chetumal and easy to reach with rental car. The road conditions are pretty good. The site is in the middle of jungles.

479334725.name: Incredible Piece of History
479334725.author: a TripAdvisor user
479334725.reviewBody:
I really wanted to visit these pyramids when our cruise ship was in Costa Maya. People kept telling us not to book shore excursions on our own and always go through the cruise line, especially when traveling far away from the port. I read all of the reviews about Native Choice and decided to chance it. I'm glad that I did. 

We had to walk about 2 blocks out of the port to get to their office, but it was easy to find. They had many different tours going in various directions, but we loaded after about a 20 minute wait. We were in a 16 passenger van which was very nice with racks above for your gear and air vents to keep it cool. Our guide was Lorenzo. The first thing he did was ask exactly when we all needed to be back at the port. He let us know that the plan was to have us back at least an hour before that.

On the way, he gave us great information on the history and area as we rode about 2 hours to Dzibanche. We went through some towns where they were selling pineapples and harvesting sugarcane.

When we got to Dzibanche, Lorenzo took us to the different structures, explaining each one, and letting us climb 2 of the pyramids. That's what sets this apart from so many of the others. You don't just walk and look, you actually get to climb to the top and see across the whole area. We got to take our time, ask questions and walk around the entire area. It was not rushed at all.

After getting back in the van, we stopped at the bathrooms before the trip back. Lorenzo passed out sandwiches, chips, granola bars and water which we could eat on the way back. I read some complaints about this, but really that's all you need. Maybe it's because we're used to packing a lunch before we head out on an adventure.

The trip back was quiet, with many people napping. We stopped briefly to take in the view of a cenote. It was then back to the port. We got there with plenty of time to spare, and our family even stopped in a shop or two.

This was an incredible site for our kids to see and I would highly recommend it. I would also have no hesitation in booking with Native Choice. They were well organized and very concerned about making sure we were all back in time. I also want to thank Lorenzo for educating us on more than just site itself. He did a great job.

478083124.name: Great
478083124.author: a TripAdvisor user
478083124.reviewBody: Very interesting and nice place in the jungle. Unfortunately the road is not very good, but driving slowly, will word the trip.

463593595.name: A nice and compact
463593595.author: a TripAdvisor user
463593595.reviewBody: This is a nice and compact site.  It is cool in the morning and there is lots of shade.  Two hours max to see it and then on adjacent sites.

462730493.name: Wow Mayan Ruins in the Raw
462730493.author: a TripAdvisor user
462730493.reviewBody: 4th Century Mayan ruins in the raw. Well worth the long coach (air conditioned) trip with a very knowledgeable guide & driver! Great photograph opportunities and climbs to the top of the temples - Great!!! Indian Jones - eat your heart out!

456692906.name: Awe inspiring Mayan Ruins
456692906.author: a TripAdvisor user
456692906.reviewBody: Well worth the visit if you love learning about Mayan history and walking through ruins of pyramids, plazas and lush greenery.  Off the beaten path and out of the way, the crowds are low and you can climb the steep pyramids if you dare for amazing views!

456461637.name: Mayan Ruins Visit
456461637.author: a TripAdvisor user
456461637.reviewBody:
Booked this trip from our Thomson cruise ship
Long drive from the coast - 2 1/2 hours
Amazing place quote literally in the middle of no where
Lots of wildlife
Toilet facilities only - no food or shops so bring your own supplies

455633727.name: Great museum!
455633727.author: a TripAdvisor user
455633727.reviewBody: Very educational & interesting history of the Mayan culture.  Some artifacts found here are in the Mayan Museum in Chetumal.   Out of all the Mayan ruins we saw, I think this one was most enjoyable & informative

454974125.name: Day Trip Off the Beaten Path
454974125.author: a TripAdvisor user
454974125.reviewBody:
Spending the day docked in Costa Maya we were looking for a place to explore and learn about ancient Mayan culture. Based on reviews on Tripadvisor we chose to travel the road less traveled and boy am I glad that we did. 

Dzibanche are rustic, largely unexplored Mayan ruins frequented by few. Our group and two local families were exploring the site at the time of our visit. We spent about 2 hours exploring the site and were permitted to climb the structures offering magnificent views of the jungle as Erick our tour guide conducted the narrated tour.

During our two hour drive to the site, passing villages with woman selling fresh pineapple, we stopped to sample local pineapple sweet, spicy and mouth watering delicious. Erick provided us with local candies and excellent commentary on the life of ancient Mayans and contemporary Mayan culture. Thank you Erick. Habner, kept his mind on the road and his hands upon the wheel while providing us safe transportation and ensured that our complimentary water was cold and our delicious box lunch, consisting of a Ham/cheese sandwich, chips and soda, was fresh and delicious. I do not normally drink soda, but Coco Cola served in Mexico is different; made with real sugar cane not high fructose corn syrup as served in the US.

Clean bathrooms were available just outside the site.

Things to bring: comfortable shoes, rain gear, insect repellent, $ for tips, $ to pay your tour balance, $ for souvenirs, binoculars (if bird watching) and map provided in email when you made online booking, key card, photo ID and a sense of adventure 

Visited December 2016

448704501.name: Fascinating, beautiful site ... somewhat remote
448704501.author: a TripAdvisor user
448704501.reviewBody: There are SO many amazing interesting Mayan sites in the Yucatan peninsula. We visited a number of them on this trip (our second time in the area) and decided to include this one after visiting Kohunlich on the same day (another awe-inspiring site).  Dzibanche is not as dramatic or large but has its own mysterious beauty. Also a horde of howler monkeys in the trees. The biggest drawback to visiting this site is the horrible roads leading to this site. The roads leading north from Highway 186 to the site are full of potholes, some of them quite large and quite capable of damaging tires and wheel rims if you\'re careless and don\'t pay attention. The archaeological site is beautiful, but I would not want to repeat this outing if the roads were in the same God-awful condition. The locals don\'t seem to care ... they just wove around the ruts and craters.  See this place if you love Mayan history but make sure you\'re very alert while driving there.

441548232.name: Amazing temple in the Mexican jungle
441548232.author: a TripAdvisor user
441548232.reviewBody: When we arrived we started wandering around on our own, and after a short walk came to an impressive temple. I\'ve seen pictures of these places before but never really appreciated how tall they actually are. When you climb to the top you can see for miles over the jungle. \n  \nWhen we came back down we were pretty happy, thinking we\'d seen everything, when we came across a member of staff, who pointed out a monkey with her baby swinging about in the trees above us. We were excited, as it was the first wild monkey we\'d seen. But then he asked if we\'d like him to show us the rest of the site. We didn\'t realise there was a rest of the site, so took him up on his offer. Again, he didn\'t speak much English, we don\'t speak much Spanish, but gradually we managed to understand each other. We were so glad we went with him. It turned out the place was huge, he took us under ropes, climbing up parts of the building we wouldn\'t have been allowed to on our own, and explaining what we were looking at. He should us parts of the temples where the original red colour had been recently restored; he explained the size of the sleeping areas for the priests; which parts of the site were used for human sacrifice, and how much of an honour that was; and even pointed out a gigantic spider, which I would have rather not seen. Dzibanche turned out to be a really impressive and interesting site.

436005227.name: You will never see anything like it
436005227.author: a TripAdvisor user
436005227.reviewBody:
A friend and colleague who was a local schoolteacher took me to Dzibanche and also to Kohunliche, which he recommended as two of the lesser known and lesser visited Mayan sites in the Yucatan. They were both breathtakingly spectacular.

I don’t know how to describe either site in a short review except to say that they were the most remarkable places I have ever visited or could have even imagined. The day we went was almost surreal – it was a sunny cloudless weekday morning and we were alone in the complexes, experiencing the beautiful silence that envelops the space and just soaking in the magic.

Whatever you may have seen about Mayan ruins from pictures, TV, whatever – it all fades bleakly into the background once you walk the grounds of one.

421190737.name: Spectacular site!
421190737.author: a TripAdvisor user
421190737.reviewBody: My first visit to Dzibanche was like a dream.  INAH does a beautiful job maintaining this archaeological zone. What a wonderful way to spend a day that should include a visit to the sister site of Kinichna.

417911938.name: good chance of seeing the howler monkeys
417911938.author: a TripAdvisor user
417911938.reviewBody: .I have been many times to this ruin.  I live fairly close, and have gone with friends a number of times.  The last 4 times I have been there, I have had the fun experience of seeing the families of howler monkeys.  It is a large ruin, very spread out and in a fairly isolated area, and I think that is why there are monkeys there so often.  Frequently there are less then 20 people on the entire ruin.  It is big, impressive and has a wide range of architectural styles.  I think it may be my favorite.  Seeing monkeys in their natural habitat, carrying their young, interacting with each other is priceless to me.

417006137.name: Book with Mayadan Adventure
417006137.author: a TripAdvisor user
417006137.reviewBody:
We had a truly excellent day visitng Dzibanche with Mayadan Adventure.
Jonathan was a great tour guide and filled us with loads of knowledge about the ruins.
We enjoyed Mayadan so much that we booked a second tour with them.
I highly recommend Mayadan Adventures.
Best to contact them via WhatsApp. Their number is available on Facebook.

408890078.name: A Truly Fantastic Day Trip!
408890078.author: a TripAdvisor user
408890078.reviewBody: Many of the Mayan temples no longer allow tourists to climb and explore.  That\'s not the case at Kohunlich.  I have fond memories from my youth visiting, climbing and exploring the ruins at Tulum, and I wanted to share a similar experience with my children, so we visited Dzibanche and Kohunlich while in port at Costa Maya.  It was a fairly long bus ride -- approximately 2.5 hours each way, but my kids LOVED the experience, and so did I.  It takes the better part of a day, but I highly recommend this experience for adventurists, historians, and families seeking quality time together.

398189852.name: Super Mayan Ruins
398189852.author: a TripAdvisor user
398189852.reviewBody: This place is immense and they are still excavating more ruins. You can still climb the steps (if you are fit), unlike most other ruins. Go with Native Choice Tours for a perfect trip. They take you there, provide a guide, provide food & water, and bring you back. The history is fascinating and well worth the time!

393564247.name: Stunning, quiet and worth the effort
393564247.author: a TripAdvisor user
393564247.reviewBody:
We drove for about 2.5 from Mahahual as we were told this is one of the few ruins that isn't over run with crowds. 
We were the only group there for much of the time and then there was only one other group. 
The ruins are spectacular, we were joined by a guide who was able explain all the history. It's mind boggling. We also saw a family of howler monkeys. 
Be aware that the guides only speak Spanish but my son with GCSE was able to translate for the rest of us. 

Despite being smothered in 50% deet we were covered in insect bites so I'd recommend long sleeves and long trousers. 

There are loos at the entrance gate but nowhere to get drinks so take plenty of water. 

You won't regret going.

377119543.name: One of the best mayan ruins I have seen do far
377119543.author: a TripAdvisor user
377119543.reviewBody: This is the best mayan ruins you can see in Costa Maya. Do it with Native\n Choice and you won\'t regret it. A lot to discover and a lot of climbing an walking.

352260053.name: A great jungle ruin near Costa Maya, Mahahual, and Bacalar
352260053.author: a TripAdvisor user
352260053.reviewBody:
We made this tour with Native Choice outside of the cruise terminal at Costa Maya. This is a long trip via a nice van to the ruins. Native Choice offices are outside of the cruise terminal, and two blocks on the left. It is about a 20 minute hike. To their office.

6 to 6 1/2 hours is what you need to this tour. We had an 8 hour lay over from the cruise ship. We were off the ship ASAP.

Having been several other Mayan ruins. I wanting to this one. It is back in the countryside and in the jungle. Yes did see Howler Monkeys. Not many (any) tourists when we visited. Enrique was our tour guide, and he was great ! I climbed one of the palaces, and sat where the kings did. The other larger temple...well my wife was getting antsy to leave. Enrique thought were still good on the time. S I did not scale it.

On the way to the ruins. We made one drink, and snack stop. Bought some extra drinks to have on the return trip. Plus some for the ruins groundskeepers.

Bring your insect repellent ! The bugs were not bad, but they could be. They definitely were flying about.

If you want where few will go. Plus maybe seeing the Monkeys. Do this one. Chacchoben is good too. Plus it is much closer,...... with the crowds too.

349519674.name: Amazing and peaceful!
349519674.author: a TripAdvisor user
349519674.reviewBody: First off I would highly recommend a tour guide.  The howler monkeys were one of the most interesting things about the ruins to us.  The sound straight out of Jurassic park and are loud and very scary sounding.  Our guide told us they are protecting territory and they stay very high up in the trees.   The ruins were amazing and peaceful.  Bring bug spray there were some mosquitos but it was very overcast and there were not that many.  One of the few places on earth you are allowed to still climb the ruins.   Probably not the best idea .  I think it\'s a matter of time before someone falls and ruins it for the rest .

338911339.name: Great interaction with history
338911339.author: a TripAdvisor user
338911339.reviewBody: We visited these ruins on a Tuesday morning. No one else but the ruin guards was there. Being able to climb to the top of the pyramids and feel history under your feet was amazing. During our trip a pack of monkey\'s was climbing through the trees and we were able to watch them for a bit. Would highly recommend a tour guide if one is available while you are there.

338551227.name: Beautiful Dzibznche ruins!!! Well worth the drive!
338551227.author: a TripAdvisor user
338551227.reviewBody: I want to thank our wonderful tour guide Diego and our driver Miguel for a great trip to the Dzibanche ruins. The drive out and back was very long (over 2 hours each way) from the cruise terminal, but was well worth the trip. You are able to climb these particular ones, if you are able. I say this because if you are at all afraid of heights you may have an issue. It can be very intimidating, especially once you get to the top and realize there is only one way to get back down.\nWe are extremely glad we booked this excursion and glad we booked with Native choice! Thanks again to Diego and Miguel!!!

325942084.name: Wondrous, Secluded Ruins
325942084.author: a TripAdvisor user
325942084.reviewBody: Dzibanche was truly awe-inspiring. I attended with a cruise-tour and was amazed. The ruins are not crowded or kitschy. While we toured them we were the only people there. You can climb the ruins and explore. Completely worth it!\n\nI would bring bug spray and a long sleeve shirt.

325563122.name: A ruin less traveled
325563122.author: a TripAdvisor user
325563122.reviewBody: Except for crews doing further excavations, we were alone with these stunning ruins. Howler monkeys greeted us\u2014or, more probably, ignored us. These are smaller Mayan ruins in the jungle of southern Quintana Roo, well off the beaten path down a windy, narrow road. One ticket gains you access to two sites; the other is a single monumental pyramid that\'s worth the effort to climb for an outstanding view. We did the hour long drive from Bacalar. Absolutely worth it.

325214797.name: Great tour and guide
325214797.author: a TripAdvisor user
325214797.reviewBody:
Booked this trip online with Native Choice and their office is a 10 minute walk from cruise terminal.
Very friendly welcome and only 2 of us on tour so became a personal trip. Joel our guide was brilliant, explained history of Mayans and took us round all the ruins. This site is the only one where you can still climb the steps.
We also saw a family of Howler monkeys which was an added bonus.
Warning..... make sure you have some mosquito repellent. Even though it was dry there were thousands of em, if it rains there will be millions. Long sleeved tops is also advisable.
After the tour on way back we were treated to sandwiches and sodas/water and there is plenty to drink at any time.
It is a 2 hour trip each way but transport is newish vehicles with aircon.
Fully recommend this trip and much cheaper than cruise tour. We paid $138 for the 2 of us.
Good luck and you will not be disappointed.

316428283.name: Mayan Secret!
316428283.author: a TripAdvisor user
316428283.reviewBody: This is a beautiful Mayan ruin with some Aztec influence.  It is off the beaten path, so we were the only guests there when we visited on a Friday morning.  There are monkeys in the trees adding to the true jungle feel.  This is an active dig site, so some areas were closed to the public.  Be sure to climb the ruins for incredible views!  It will be a sad day if this attraction becomes overrun so enjoy it while few now about its beauty!  And wear insect repellent or expect to be miserable!

304530538.name: Great trip from Mahahual to Dzibanch\u00e9 and Kinachn\u00e1
304530538.author: a TripAdvisor user
304530538.reviewBody: Prebooked trip with Native Choice in Mahahual.  Walked to Native Choice building from the cruise ship terminal.  This walk was about 10 mins.  After paying for the trip, we got into an air-conditioned van that seated about 10 people. Joel our friendly guide described the upcoming trip to Dzibanch\u00e9.  The trip to Dzibanch\u00e9 took about two and a half hours. At Dzibanch\u00e9, Joel was excellent in relating the Mayan culture and history with the various temples and palaces and locations.  After a little over an hour walking around the park-like grounds and climbing up a temple and palace, we left Dzibanch\u00e9 for Kinachn\u00e1 about two kilometres down the road.  All in all,  a highly recommended trip.  Native Choice provided sandwiches, pop and water during the trip. These were included in the trip pricing.  Joel was a great guide and Able an excellent driver.  Total round trip about six hours.

267640361.name: Go To Dzibanche And Take Reggie With You!!!
267640361.author: a TripAdvisor user
267640361.reviewBody: During a winter 6 week stay in the Yucatan on the shores of Laguna Bacalar, my wife and I, and my cousin, hired a wonderful and expert certified Mayan Ruins tour guide named Reggie to take us for a day trip to Dzibanche and Kohunlich. This was after we had used his services in a prior visit to the Chacchoben Mayan Ruins northwest of Bacalar, having had a spectacularly good time learning about the ancient and sophisticated Mayan culture and civilization. Being of Mayan descent himself, Reggie was extremely knowledgeable and enthusiastic in telling us about the unique details of each site. He also taught us much about the flora, fauna, and animal life of each locality. He spoke excellent English and had a fantastic sense of humor, such that we felt entirely comfortable kidding back and forth during our time spent together. In fact, on a later occasion back in Bacalar, we invited Reggie and his beautiful wife Elizabeth to meet us at a restaurant for dinner, getting to know them on a more personal level, and coming to an even greater appreciation of what genuine, good-hearted people they are. The Dzibanche, Kohunlich, and Chacchoben ruins were all very impressive and exciting to see in their largely intact jungle settings, and without the crowds of people that flock to the more barren landscape of Chichen Itza, which my wife and I have also visited. New discoveries are still being made and being prepared for public viewing at these sites, and you get the sense that you are seeing, literally, groundbreaking archeological finds that few people have yet seen. We thoroughly appreciated Reggie\'s unhurried guidance through all of the sites, allowing us to take plenty of photos for a lifetime of good memories and sharing with others. We highly recommend seeing these sites and taking Reggie with you to fully understand and appreciate them! He lives in Bacalar and may be contacted at ReginoSeptiembre2012@hotmail.com.

265279119.name: Dzibanche and Kinichna Ruins
265279119.author: a TripAdvisor user
265279119.reviewBody: My son-in-law booked this trip  on line through Costa Maya Cruise Excursions.   I can\'t say enough good things about our tour.   We had 9 visitors in our van and Gus, our tour guide, was very informative.   We learned about the history of the area, the plants, the animals, ...he even stopped and got us some pineapple to taste after he told us about the different pineapples.   We learned about the small coconuts that are carved into animals, the gum tree with samples of the tree and the final product, and after our 2 hour drive to the ruins, we learned about the history of the ruins.

263819877.name: Amazing to climb, but be ready for a long drive
263819877.author: a TripAdvisor user
263819877.reviewBody:
Our cruise was ported in Mahahual (Costa Maya), so we knew it was going to be a long trip. The drive was about 2.5 hours in both directions, so it was a very close call for us to make it back to the ship.

That being said...

YOU HAVE TO DO THESE RUINS! I have done ruins in Greece, Peru, etc. and was absolutely blown away by these. You can tell how nature overtook them, with winding roots embedded within the rocks. I am scared of heights, and getting up the ruins was easy. Getting down not so much. I went down on my butt and had no problem.

I would NOT recommend going here for people with walking or balance difficulties. If you are on a cruise and want to see Mayan ruins, go somewhere closer. However, if you want a once-in-a-lifetime experience, come to these.

As others have stated, there was no one there with us, which was the best part. You could take your time and not worry about all of the crowds.

263133343.name: Dzibanche and Kuhunlich - accessible and worth seeing
263133343.author: a TripAdvisor user
263133343.reviewBody: These two ruins are a short drive from Chetumal and are well worth the trip.   No crowds, only 64 pesos to get in, and they are in great condition.  Avoid the crowds at Chichen Itza!

260796129.name: The history was cool
260796129.author: a TripAdvisor user
260796129.reviewBody: This was our first cruise ever so I didn\'t know what to expect. We booked this and Kohinlinch. Our tour guide Daniel was great he kept our interest on the 2.5 hour bus ride giving us lots of facts.

259445418.name: Wonderful
259445418.author: a TripAdvisor user
259445418.reviewBody: We chose this as a tour (which was paired with Kohinlich) as we wanted to see Mayan temples and ruins. we weren\'t disappointed. the sites are fairly remote and therefore unspoilt. There is no commercial activity at all (so no vendors or facilities) but that adds to the remote exotic feel. we could also climb some of the temples. If you are into history this is a must do. I also found the local Mexicans so nice and friendly - such a contrast to the surly unhelpful Jamacians we encountered elsewhere on our cruise. I highly recommend this site - but its not suitable for the elderly or anyone with mobility issues. It was also very hot (and it wasnt even their summer - so be prepared!).

258474027.name: Excellent tour with Native Choice Tours
258474027.author: a TripAdvisor user
258474027.reviewBody: We booked this tour on our own, not with the cruise ship. Our tour consisted of about 8 visitors, a driver, and our outstanding and very knowledgeable guide, David. So much history was learned in our 6 hour tour. Exciting to see the preservation work being done at the time of our visit since David explained the amount of detail required, the level of restoration expertise of the artists doing the work  and the importance of the work being done.

255694612.name: Far exceeded our expectations
255694612.author: a TripAdvisor user
255694612.reviewBody: I didn\'t think this trip was going to happen.  I had tried to book a visit to Kobunlich and Dzibanche in advance and just didn\'t have any luck.  But fortunately as we were leaving Casitas Carolina for breakfast on our first morning, my husband asked Modesto who is one of the staff members there if he knew of anyone who does that kind of tour.  He came up with Reggie who was a real jem.  Before we knew it, Reggie had hired a cab (another jem named Candelaria, cab #36) and we were on our way to both sites.  Reggie\'s explanation of the history, the Mayan calendar and the architecture was complete and insightful.  A real bonus was that we were able to see restoration at work with workers making the fine sand needed for stucco and others applying the stucco with tiny spatulas.  The howler monkeys provided tremendous roars as a backdrop to this exquisite tour.  As we left, the spider monkeys seemed to all gather on cue for our departure.  What an experience!  Reggie\'s email is ReginoSeptiembre2012@hotmail.com.

249925278.name: Costa Maya cruise ship excursion
249925278.author: a TripAdvisor user
249925278.reviewBody: My wife and I took the excursion for Dzibanche and Kohunlich Mayan ruins. We had gone to San Gervasio on Cozumel Island the day before. Dzibanche was the first of the two that we visited and we were blown away by the size of these ruins. I wasn\'t overly excited to climb the ruins as it seemed like a destructive thing to do, but I ended up doing it for the experience as well as the vantage point to see more detail. There was some reconstruction going on during our visit and it was interesting to see how they put these ruins back together.\n\nIt is a long drive from Costa Maya, but our bus was very comfortable (then again, it was only 80 degrees in January.) This site has a good history and some great detail that does add to the Kohunlich site which is a bit larger and awe inspiring. When leaving Dzibanche you will be able to see ruins in the hills across from the park and if you keep a sharp eye you can see other ruins all over the area.

249024777.name: Great option for cruise excursion
249024777.author: a TripAdvisor user
249024777.reviewBody: If you are into history, this is the place. We took the Princess excursion to Dzibanche and Kohunlich which is about 1/2 hour from here. This is an all day bus tour from the Costa Maya port. It takes 2-2.5 hours one way to the sites. We took a nice air conditioned bus. The sites are amazing piece of 300-600 AD Mayan history. You are free to climb around and explore. The other plus is that the sites are not tourist traps. There are very few people at the sites. Fairly easy walking and climbing. There are rest rooms at each site. Not a handicap friendly place.

247788211.name: Phenomenal Site Which Can Be Reached From Cruise Ships in Costa Maya
247788211.author: a TripAdvisor user
247788211.reviewBody: We used the Native Choice tour to get to Dzibanche from our cruise ship in Costa Maya.  They were excellent as was our guide Erick.  While the drive to get to Dzibanche is long, this site is nothing short of phenomenal and is not to be missed.  You can still climb on many of these pyramids and they are really good shape.  The second highest Mayan structure in Mexico is at Dzibanche.  If you do anything in Costa Maya take this tour.  No fighting crowds at this site.  While it was not offered by our cruise line (Norweigan) as an option it is so much better than the options that were offered.  My only theory as to why is that the very last few miles of approach may not conducive to the use of large buses.  This is a blessing, no cruise ship crowds and ability to see the view that the Mayan rulers had from the top.  It was the highlight of our vacation.

244268559.name: Worth the drive
244268559.author: a TripAdvisor user
244268559.reviewBody: Dzibanche Mayan ruins were very well preserved. Much more than just a crumbling wall that other locations may have. There were several pyramids or towers you could climb for an extra special view. Highly recommended if you are in the area. We went to Dzibanche from a shore excursion that left from Costa Maya and it was about a 2.5 hour drive. Once you\'re there you are only another 30 minutes from the also spectacular ruins at Kohunlich. Go to both!  \n\nThe bugs ate me alive even with bug spray. I highly recommend wearing long sleeves and long pants and thoroughly spraying with a high deet spray all over any exposed areas. I wore long sleeves and shorts and walked away with a couple bites on my hands, neck and about 10 on my legs.

243484337.name: You won\'t be disappointed
243484337.author: a TripAdvisor user
243484337.reviewBody: We took the Native Choice tour to these ruins (see separate review of Native Choice) and they were excellent.  We were the only party there so we had the entire site to ourselves to explore at leisure.  Our guide (Erick) was excellent and gave a very thorough tour, including climbing three of the pyramids.  Well worth seeing!

243327474.name: Beautiful spot!
243327474.author: a TripAdvisor user
243327474.reviewBody: We loved the history behind the ruins and our guide was fabulous!  There were howler monkeys in the jungle on the way to climb to the top..It was high..and not for the faint of heart!  Our teenagers loved it though,

243103599.name: Tour with "The Native Choice"
243103599.author: a TripAdvisor user
243103599.reviewBody: We booked online, only had to pay a small deposit. We were only four people in the group. Nice mini bus, air-conditioned. Guide had cooler with water, soda, juice, sandwiches and chips.\nThe Ruins ground is fantastic and we were the only ones there! If you dare to climb the ruins you get a great look over the area. Guide spoke English very well. We were back at the pier with over an hour to spare. Costs very reasonable, much better than the cruise ship! Highly recommend it!

240461492.name: Dzibanche and Kinichna Tour, Native Choice
240461492.author: a TripAdvisor user
240461492.reviewBody: We booked the tour online with the Native Choice before our cruise, and easily walked the ~0.5mi from the tourist trap of Costa Maya out to their office.  We hopped onto the van and were off to the ruins in a few minutes.  The van was very nice, but the road from Costa Maya to the main highway was pretty bouncy (~30 mins).  People with motion sickness should reconsider any tour that goes on that highway.  Once onto regular roads it was smooth sailing to the ruins, with a short gas pitstop about 1 hour in.  Total round trip drive time was around 2.5-3 hours (~240mi) and was pretty nice overall.  We stopped at the welcome center and went on to Dzibanche, where we were the only 6 people in the entire complex.  Great views, great pictures, and you can climb at least 3 or 4 different ruins.  After that we went to nearby Kinichna, which is just as impressive and climbable.  Our guide gave us tons of information en route and at the site, with very good english.  Our driver was very professional did a great job as well.  They provided water, sodas and a sandwich/chips/crackers on leaving Kinichna.  The only negative of the whole experience (5 stars overall!!) was that you need a LOT of bug spray.  The black flies swarmed us with the "orange can" OFF provided by the tour, fortunately I had the "green can" with me that kept them at bay for the rest of the trip.  I HIGHLY recommended this tour and tour company, especially to stay clear of the tourist traps like Chacchoben.

236730000.name: The real experience.
236730000.author: a TripAdvisor user
236730000.reviewBody: This is what a Mayan  experience should be. No T-shirt salesman, No crowds. My wife and me were the only people there at the time. It was like we were the first people to discover the place. The ruins and cravings are not to be missed. If your a birder, this is a great place. Lots of species moving all over the area. It only cost $4.50 WHAT A BARGAIN..

230409139.name: Dzibanche Ruins in Costa Maya through The Native Choice
230409139.author: a TripAdvisor user
230409139.reviewBody: My husband and I booked our Dzibanche Maya Ruins Tour excursion through The Native Choice instead of Carnival to get away from the "cruise crowds" (aka "moo tourists") and we were very impressed with the price, value, and service.  The Native Choice\'s confirmation included everything needed; from detailed instructions about where to meet, what to bring/wear, and what to do if cruise dates changed (we went at peak hurricane season!).  We were the only two people on this excursion with our very knowledgeable guide, David.  David made the two hour drive seem too short as he taught us about the site we would visit, the areas through which we traveled, and about Mayan and world history.  Dzibanche is a very remote and quiet (other than toucans and howler monkeys) location and other than a maintenance worker, it was just us and our guide...and the wildlife.  Many of the buildings/pyramids/temples have been excavated and restored and many have not.  Only the main pyramid was closed as it was still being excavated.  David also knew about plants that help ward off mosquitoes, which were thankfully not a problem on our visit.  If you want a more personal excursion at a lower cost, I highly recommend The Native Choice....and ask for David!

230203199.name: Just us and the security guard
230203199.author: a TripAdvisor user
230203199.reviewBody: Hot, rainy, and deserted.  We didn\'t mind.  This is a great site and a must see if you enjoy Mayan Ruins.  The companion site included in the fee, M$160 for two, Kinich Na, was also very interesting.  Great climbing.  Only two locations were closed off.  On this excursion, take time to go see Kokunlich.

208279264.name: Dzibanche ruins
208279264.author: a TripAdvisor user
208279264.reviewBody: This remote site felt untouched and very well preserved.  In fact, there are so many surrounding ruins that are still being excavated!  We used the Native Choice tours out of Costa Maya from our cruise ship.  Our guide Erick was great.  He gave us a history lesson on the Mayans and was very knowledgeable.  My favorite story he told us was how the Yucatan peninsula was named.  The Spanish asked "What is this land called?", to which the Mayans replied "I hear you speaking, but I don\'t understand you".  This sounded to the Spanish like "Yucatan".  \nI would HIGHLY recommend bug spray as you\'ll get eaten alive!

201823657.name: Fantastic
201823657.author: a TripAdvisor user
201823657.reviewBody:
100 pesos entry for two people.  Dzibanche means "Writing on Wood".Also, this fee covers a smaller ruin site nearby called Kinichna which means "House of the Sun".  Huge tree canopy and very few people. 

 While walking towards exit we heard blood curdling screams.  Daniel the attendant at site was nice enough to lead us down a pathway and pointed out the howler monkeys in the trees to us.  The male was making these incredible loud screams and the female was with a baby and adolescent in another tree.    Watched them and attempted to get some photos.  

Continued our walk down another pathway leading back to our car and about 20 spider monkeys went flying through the trees right above us.  It was a spectacular show.  A truly amazing sight.  Tried to get some pictures as they went flying through.  Tree branches and leaves raining down on us.  So memorable.

196250795.name: Dzibanche ruins
196250795.author: a TripAdvisor user
196250795.reviewBody: A very well kept site with the ability to get right up to the ancient structures.  Really worth seeing and taking photos.  The place is not crowded and easy to get around but be prepared to do some walking over rough ground.  Puts Egypt to shame.

196224463.name: The Natice Choice Guided Tour of Dzibanche
196224463.author: a TripAdvisor user
196224463.reviewBody: Great tour of the Mayan Ruin Dzibanche. Not visited as much so very pleasant. We toured with Native Choice. Our tour guide Erick was very knowledgable being a Mayan decendant himself. Ruins were astounding. Listening to the monkeys in the trees was an extra added bonus, even if they did sound like werewolfs. Worth the trip! Greg - Arizona

188315037.name: Indiana Jones has been here
188315037.author: a TripAdvisor user
188315037.reviewBody: This place is the best Mayan Ruin so far and we have been to about 5 so far. There were only nine people at the site , very few people know about it. You can climb to the top of all 4 ruins and some people were even on the cruise ship and we made it back in time, I would recommend not going with a tour that has to get the cruise guys back though the speed back was scary. Once you see my photo you will know you must go best choice we made. GO

164734768.name: Well worth seeing
164734768.author: a TripAdvisor user
164734768.reviewBody: We visited these Mayan ruins in January 2013. We hired a private guide to take us around the site and tell us the history of the ruins. The jungle setting is very beautiful and the ruins are fascinating. This is a must-do trip on any travellers to-do list! Remember to wear flat comfortable shoes so you can climb up the ruins and don\'t forget to bring water (you are in the jungle and there are few facilities!). When we were there it was very hot and sunny - so bring a hat and sun cream. We also saw and heard lots of the howler monkeys that occupy the site.

164354836.name: One of the best Mayan ruins in the south of the Yucatan peninsula
164354836.author: a TripAdvisor user
164354836.reviewBody:
If you are tired  of visiting Chichenitza, Tulum or Coba with thousands of other tourists every day and would like to experience the real Mayan ruins feeling all by yourself, then exploring Dzibanche and the nearby Mayan palace of Kinich-Na  might be an alternative. You would ,however, need a rental car in order to drive some 200 miles or roughly 350 km from the Cancun area and the Riviera Maya to Chetumal, the capital of the Mexican state of Quintanaroo located at  the southern  end of the Yucatan peninsula close to the borders of Belize and Guatemala. Because of the distance between Cancun or the Riviera Maya and the Chetumal area and the fact that there are no tourist accomodations available near Dzibanche you may want to stay overnight in either Chetumal or Bacalar. Bacalar is known for the clear blue water of the Bacalar Lagoon and probably the better choice for a hotel right at the lagoon. 

From either Bacalar or Chetumal you follow the signs to Carretera (federal highway) 186 in the direction of  Escarcega. After roughly 35 miles or 55 km on 186  you will see the blue sign on the right hand side of the highway directing you to Dzibanche. You leave the highway and follow a small country road for the remaining 15 miles (some 25 km) to the ruins of Dzibanche. While driving on the carretera is fine, the country road for the remaining distance to the ruins 
is covered with potholes and cracks of the pavement on the sides will require you to go slow. But the driving experience on Mexican countryroads for visiting Dzibanche, a unique site located virtually in the middle of the jungle, is very much worth the effort. The silence at the surpringly well kept site was only interrupted by the singing of birds and playful monkeys. We found Dzibanche absolutely magnificent and except for a Mexican family were the only visitors during the entire time of our 4 hour visit. Make sure you bring plenty of water as there is no place to buy anything at the ruins. If you speak Spanish the ranger supervising the site will answer most of your questions and turned out to be very helpful. What we liked most at this vast site with numerous temples, pyramids and sacred structures was not only the feeling to be in the middle of the jungle but also that there were almost no signs and ropes prohibiting the access to the buildings and pyramids. Being allowed to climb up to the top of the various structures and exploring the sacred buildings without the typical tourist crowd was sensational!
Not to mention the breathtaking views of the vast site and the thick jungle from the top of the pyramids. 

After visiting Dzibanche the ranger recommended that we don`t miss the large acropolis of nearby Kinich-Na, only a mile away. The acropolis was at one time part of Dzibanche and is the only building complex at this site, but what a magnificent structure with various temples on three levels. A climb up to the third level of the acropolis will give you a terrific  view of the area which you will not forget. 

If you are interested in Mayan ruins and want to get a feel of what it was like visiting Chichenitza, Tulum or Coba some 40 years ago,  you should visit  Dzibanche and Kinich-Na if you have the time.

158508746.name: Excellent day trip from cruise port
158508746.author: a TripAdvisor user
158508746.reviewBody: Our family (mom,dad,and 2 teens) just returned from West Carib cruise. We booked day trip from Costa Maya port to Dzibanche-Kinchna with El Tucan de Costa Maya through their website. No problem with reservation or finding kiosk just outside of port gate. We were the only people booked for the day so our guide, Ms. Maria Rosado, drove us to the ruins in her private vehicle which was quite comfortable. She is part Mayan, has helped in some of the excavating of ruins, and speaks perfect English. The trip takes about 2 hours each way but it is worth the travel time. The ruins are in excellent condition and we were able to climb to the top of multiple large pyramid-like structures(easy going up-but tricky getting down!). Besides literally having the ruins to ourselves, Ms. Maria educated us and answered numerous questions we had about the Mayan culture. I highly recommend this tour if you are interested in viewing Mayan ruins without busloads of other cruisers.

156905479.name: A magical place away from the hoards
156905479.author: a TripAdvisor user
156905479.reviewBody: Going to this site, you feel like you could be the person discovering it for the first time. There is noone else there so it really feels magical. You can climb to the top - where you feel like king of the jungle.

155068028.name: Dzibanch\u00e9 Ruins with Toucan Costa Maya Tours. GREAT EXPERIENCE!
155068028.author: a TripAdvisor user
155068028.reviewBody: Booked Dzibanch\u00e9-Kinichn\u00e1 Ruins with Toucan Costa Maya Tours for almost HALF a price than the tour offered by the cruise. Maria(guide) and Carlos(driver) are bi-lingual, VERY knowleadge, HONEST people, they go the "extra mile" over and over again! They stopped at the road during the 2 hr. trip and shared with us FREE sandwichs,pineaples, water, traditional "tamales" and coconut water that weren\'t included in the tour! The site(Dzibanch\u00e9-Kinichn\u00e1) was AMAZING, pristine, and we ended up being THE only people in the whole site, with plenty of time to climb the pyramids. I will highly recommend Toucan of Costa maya Tour!!

154993354.name: Beautiful site
154993354.author: a TripAdvisor user
154993354.reviewBody: My wife and I booked a shore excursion to Dzibanche through Native Choice. The company was launching a number of tours near the port at Costa Maya and were efficient and organized in getting the shows on the road. It was about a two hour drive to Dzibanche with one pit stop enroute. The twenty miles or so from the port is mostly swamp and undeveloped. Might be boring to some but we found it fascinating. The last part of the trip goes through miles of sugar cane fields that were being harvested. Dzibanche is remote and I think we were the third and last group of the day to visit. It is well restored and maintained. It is good sized but not huge. Our guide Francisco had done considerable research into this site and his knowledge exceeded what you would normally expect from a guide. The site is organized into clusters of squares and temples, often from different periods. The beauty is hard to describe - pictures tell a better story. We climbed the tallest pyramid which has a view of near by Kohunlich. Getting up was okay, getting down was an adventure. If you have an issue with heights, as I do, go down slowly backwards or on your rear end step by step. For the last 45 - 60 minutes we [about 12] were the only group at  the site. It really felt like you were in another era.  On the trip the van had mechanical problems and eventually came to a full stop an hour away from the ship. I was impressed with the way Francisco and the driver handled the situation. They were in constant contact with their office, another van was dispatched from Costa Maya and a tour that had gone to Kohunlich stopped had took on a number of us. We were never in any danger of missing the boat and arrived back at Costa Maya before some of the ship sponsored excursions. Their business depends on getting tours back on time and they were prepared for this glitch.

154358237.name: Dzbanche Ruins
154358237.author: a TripAdvisor user
154358237.reviewBody: We drove ourselves from Bacalar and had a great day doing a self guided tour of the ruins.  We came prepared with guide books and plenty of water and our climbing shoes.  The grounds are beautiful and al the buildings are well described.  We enjoyed the jungle setting, but missed the monkeys.  Well worth the drive!

151854881.name: The second of three closely related archaeological sites
151854881.author: a TripAdvisor user
151854881.reviewBody: The owner of La Posada Chetumal Hostel arranged this taxi tour of Kohunlich, Dzibanche and Kinichna for me.  My share of the taxi fare came to 300 pesos.  The entry fee to this site was 46 pesos.  There was no discount for having visited Kohunlich on the same day.  There is said to be evidence linking this site to the one a Calakmul.  The howler monkeys must have thought that I was lonely, being at the site almost by myself, and so they provided me a serenade.  There is an interesting stucco work available for viewing as well as interesting architectural features.  I was able to freely climb the pyramids.

151123263.name: Dzibanche
151123263.author: a TripAdvisor user
151123263.reviewBody: Booked a private tour through the Native Choice.  Dzibanche is quite a distance from Costa Maya our cruise port.  The trip through this part of the Yucatan was worth the time spent getting there. Our guide, Enrique and driver Edgar kept us comfortable at all times. These ruins are amazing.\nEnrique is a wealth of knowledge.  It almost felt as we were living during the times of the Maya. And yes we heard and saw Howler Monkeys.  Another treat.  What made it special was that there was no-one else there.  Had the place all to ourselves.\nIf you are willing to spend the time getting there and discover an important place for the Mayans I suggest you visit.

150369528.name: Worth the extra drive
150369528.author: a TripAdvisor user
150369528.reviewBody: Wow! Such a fantastic yet unsung gem of a place. We arrived mid morning and there was only a small group of tourists already there. Our group of 6 must have startled the spider monkeys, 40 feet above us, in the trees. We were spellbound as we watched them sloop from branch to branch, further into the jungle. The ruins were wonderfully restored. We climbed two of them for a most amazing view. Native Choice tours was again fantastic as they were our guides last year for Chaccoban.

150115141.name: Incredible experience
150115141.author: a TripAdvisor user
150115141.reviewBody: This is far enough off the beaten path that you might be one of three cars in the lot, as we were.
