We were often alone as we walked from site to site and even climbing those that we could. This was one of the wildest experiences for us because we, first heard then watched, warring howler monkeys. They are on the critically endangered list and have a truly hair-raising cry. I highly recommend this.

149129845.name: Great quiet site - if you time it right!
149129845.author: a TripAdvisor user
149129845.reviewBody: We were warned that this site was on the cruise ship tour list and therefore can be busy - we;; when we gpt there today there was a coach party in but they were the only other visitors there apart from us and when they left we had the place to ourselves - it is a wonderful site with some stunning buildings - well worth the vosit!

149068280.name: A hidden treasure
149068280.author: a TripAdvisor user
149068280.reviewBody: Our family of four visited Dzibanche 27.December 2012. It was an amazing experience to explore all these ancient buildings, and to see what is still left for the archaeologists to excavate. A big bonus was the ability to climb the ruins, and that this place was so peaceful. In addition to our group of eight persons, only one other group was there.\n\nWe travelled with The Native Choice (via Shore Excursions from Costa Maya), and Franscisco made our trip unforgettable.

147385503.name: Wow, What a Site!
147385503.author: a TripAdvisor user
147385503.reviewBody:
I visited Dzibanche while my cruise ship was in port using Native Choice.  I was originally booked for another site (the smaller set of Mayan ruins) and was the only person that booked that.  Several guides urged me to join a small group going to Dzibanche instead, although they would still honor a trip to the other site alone if I preferred.  I put up a bit of a fuss at first thinking that it was just to save money.  The guides all swore that Dzibanche was a much better site, and I committed to write a nasty review if this was a bad bait-and-switch maneuver.  I am happy to admit that I was REALLY pleased that I switched as Dzibanche is a FANTASTIC site.

Dzibanche is huge and currently being uncovered and partially restored for stability or where it is a simple matter to place some stones back in place.  I've seen some great sites around the world, but this one was one of the least populated for its size and grandeur that I have visited.  (Only 15 visitors on a nice day in November!)  

There are several large temples and other buildings in great shape currently uncovered at the site and literally square miles of buildings left to be retaken from the vegetation over time.

Native choice was great.  Our guide was very knowledgeable and honest when he didn't know something.  He helped occupy the long ride there with an interesting and accurate discussion of the Mayan history, and even a lesson in Mayan calendar reading without any of the silliness as we approached the end of 2012.  There was a separate driver so he was able to chat with us in the back of the van including a good deal of pictures related to finds at the site.  The kids and adults were interested alike.  Pricing was more than fair and everything was safe and comfortable for the entire excursion.  Time was not a problem at all regardless of what your cruise line may try to tell you to keep you from booking on your own. 

I walked away thinking it was a great day and that Dzibanche was a greatly under-visited site. I would highly recommend it to anyone with even a mild interest in archaeology or the Mayan society.

146710282.name: mayan ruins off the beaten path
146710282.author: a TripAdvisor user
146710282.reviewBody: Took this tour with Native Choice off our cruise ship. Our guide was Miguel. He was very informative and outgoing. You will have plenty of time coming off a cruise ship to get to the ruins and back. The roads are all paved. It is a long trip though. I would give it serious thought if traveling with young children or as in our case bickering teenagers. I especially enjoyed seeing the Yucatan countryside and little villages, including the women along the road selling pineapples and coconuts and baked goods.The ruins are impressive. There were a lot more structures than i had anticipated. The ruins are dispersed in a well shaded forest so it wasn\'t too hot and bugs were not an issue although we came prepared. (The tour provides bottled water.) I chose these ruins because you can still climb these ruins (although i am a little torn on that subject since climbing no doubt damages the ruins) and because these ruins are off the beaten track so there are very few people there. Infact at the beginning we were the only group there until three other small groups arrived. We were alotted 1 1/2 hr to visit the ruins which was plenty of time to appreciate the area and return tot he ship in a timely fashion.

145688684.name: Best Preserved Mayan Woodwork and Some Big Pyramids
145688684.author: a TripAdvisor user
145688684.reviewBody: Dzibanche is about 50 kilometers west of Chetumal on highway 186 headed towards Escarcega. Coming from Chetumal, you turn right onto a paved road with a few large potholes and some nasty long and tire-wide cracks that look like they are from an earthquake. About 10 kilometers up the road, a smaller paved road turns off to the right and continues another 15 kilometers past Morocoy to the ticket booth at a fork in the road. The right fork heads to Dzibanche after a kilometer or so although there is a large structure (closed but viewable from road) just to the left a few hundred meters past the ticket booth. There is a shaded path for a few hundred meters to the site, which has several large pyramids including one which has the best surviving Mayan woodwork on a lintel near the top. Most pyramids are climbable although one at the back is being restored and closed.. Two big tour buses while we were there. Cost is 46 pesos with free parking. The same ticket is good for Kinichna, which id down the left fork of the road about 3 kilometers. Toilets at the ticket booth but no refreshments.

127249450.name: Amazing and Mystical
127249450.author: a TripAdvisor user
127249450.reviewBody: We had the opportunity of traveling to Dzibanhe and although, it was a 2 hour ride from our cruise ship it was well worth the travel time. It is truly amazing. You are even able to scale some of the structures there. What I liked the most is was not tourist trampled and congested.  In fact we were the first group ( there were5 of us) that went there in like 8 days. If you like this kind of excursion this is a must see. Our guide was so well versed that on the ride over he had pictures and copies of things to view that really kept our minds working until we go there. We bought our tour through priceline and we found it about 25.00 cheaper that through our cruise ship.

124093348.name: A nice little site -- and you\'ll likely have it to yourselves
124093348.author: a TripAdvisor user
124093348.reviewBody: Dzibanch\u00e9 isn\'t the biggest of Maya ruins, but it\'s got a fair number of structures to see (most are climbable), many have been restored, and more seem to be in the process of restoration.  Best of all, this site is nearly "undiscovered" by the big tours -- you\'ll be lucky if you see anybody else when you visit.\n\nBTW, the road in is paved although it\'s got a few potholes -- so ignore the tour books that describe Dzibanch\u00e9 as a difficult drive (they just need to be updated).

122291887.name: Nicest Maya ruin near Chetumal
122291887.author: a TripAdvisor user
122291887.reviewBody: This is my favorite ruin located near Chetumal. The Temple of the Owls is very nice and there are a few other structures at the site as well. Normally, a troop of black howler monkeys hang out at the site.

121719637.name: explore without the crowds
121719637.author: a TripAdvisor user
121719637.reviewBody: amazing adventure. tucan tours in costa maya is a hidden gem. private van  at $260  total for four adults , 7 hours including lunch, tour entry fees and private knowledgeable guide. do not miss kinichna and climb for a spectacular view.

120829140.name: Remarkable piece of history - Native Choice was fantastic
120829140.author: a TripAdvisor user
120829140.reviewBody: Booking this trip through Native Choice we ended up in a van with only one other couple from our cruise ship.  The site was basically empty when we got there as this is not the popular choice for mayan ruins tours.  It was unreal.  Our guide, was very knowledgeable and seemed to have a passion for showing and explaining this cultures fascinating history.  We saw artifacts, ruins, palaces, workers quarters, and sites that have not even been uncovered yet.  You need to visit Dzibanche when in Costa Maya.

120803307.name: Great place to explore Mayan Ruins and see monkeys
120803307.author: a TripAdvisor user
120803307.reviewBody:
I've never before been to any Mayan ruins, so I don't have anything to compare this to, but I would highly recommend visiting Dzibanche if you are in the area near Chetumal or Bacalar. 

The brochure describes the site this way:
"Deep in the forest of Southern Quintana Roo, Dzibanche is the area's most important Mayan site. Once a powerful city which flourished from around AD 300-1200, it had trade, political and military links with nearby Kohunlich and rival centers in Southern Campeche and in Guatemala."

The site itself is huge with 5 substantial structures, many of which you can climb to the top. There are also a few smaller structures for those of us a bit afraid of steep steps. 

The highlight for me is that the ruins are carved out of the wooded jungle. The woods offer plenty of shade but be sure to wear long pants and use lots of bug spray. I was not prepared and ended up covered in mosquito bites. 

You also have a chance to see wildlife in person. While we were waiting for a member of our group to wander back our way, a man approached us and pointed to where they had seen some howler monkeys. It didn't take long for us to find a group of 8-10 monkeys, including babies, and we stood under the trees and watched them for about 30 minutes before they headed off into the distance. It was the highlight for me of the day. 

Your admission also includes access to another nearby ruin so you could easily make a day of going to both.
